rename.from: [BUG] list artifacts http 500 error for proxied uploads
rename.to: [BUG] Server list artifacts http 500 error for proxied uploads

body: @joaquinco thank you for bringing this to our attention! We'll be working on a fix for this.
I can confirm updating from release 1.23.1 to release 1.24.0 fixed this issue in my environment.
Yeap, worked for me too. Thanks for your work!
@joaquinco thank you for bringing it to our attention. We truly appreciate community feedback like this.

Found a problem...

If I start the UI server first, using an empty database, and then start the artifact server, the artifacts are not shown on the UI. However, if I start the artifact server first, it works and the files are shown on the UI.


> OBS: 
There are no errors on the log. 
Before starting the server, delete the database.
mlflow version = 1.24.0

```bash
# UI Server
mlflow server --host 0.0.0.0 \
  --port 8000 \
  --serve-artifacts \
  --backend-store-uri sqlite:///./site.db \
  --default-artifact-root mlflow-artifacts://localhost:8001
```
```bash
# Artifact Server
export AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID="AWS_KID"
export AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY="AWS_SKEY"
mlflow server --host 0.0.0.0 \
  --port 8001 \
  --serve-artifacts \
  --artifacts-only \
  --backend-store-uri sqlite:///./site.db \
  --artifacts-destination s3://mlflow-test-bucket
```

```python
# main.py
import mlflow
import os

mlflow.set_tracking_uri('http://localhost:8000')
with mlflow.start_run():
    mlflow.log_param("a", 1)
    mlflow.log_metric("b", 2)

    if not os.path.exists("outputs"):
        os.makedirs("outputs")

    with open("outputs/test.txt", "w") as f:
        f.write("hello world")

    print('log artifacts s')
    mlflow.log_artifact("outputs/test.txt")
    mlflow.set_tracking_uri('http://localhost:8000')
    print('log artifacts e')

```

I noticed that when starting the ui first, the URI for the experiment on the table is `mlflow-artifacts://0.0.0.0:8001/0`, and when starting the artifact server first the URI is `mlflow-artifacts://0`
I've tested it today (01/03) around 13:00 UTC.

@leviplj The issue seems to be that your `UI Server` *and* your `Artifact Server` are both configured with `--serve-artifacts`. When you attempt to list artifacts via the UI, a ListArtifacts request is sent to the `UI Server`, which thinks that it's serving artifacts and attempts to resolve them from the default `--artifacts-destination` of `./mlruns`. If you restart your `UI Server` and omit `--serve-artifacts`, everything should work as intended.

We'll work on adding a warning here and clarifying the docs.

@dbczumar Not using `--serve-artifacts` on the `UI Server`, throws the following error on the terminal when I open the run on the browser:
```bash
2022/03/02 11:00:07 ERROR mlflow.server: Exception on /ajax-api/2.0/preview/mlflow/artifacts/list [GET]
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/flask/app.py", line 2073, in wsgi_app
    response = self.full_dispatch_request()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/flask/app.py", line 1518, in full_dispatch_request
    rv = self.handle_user_exception(e)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/flask/app.py", line 1516, in full_dispatch_request
    rv = self.dispatch_request()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/flask/app.py", line 1502, in dispatch_request
    return self.ensure_sync(self.view_functions[rule.endpoint])(**req.view_args)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/mlflow/server/handlers.py", line 327, in wrapper
    return func(*args, **kwargs)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/mlflow/server/handlers.py", line 385, in wrapper
    return func(*args, **kwargs)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/mlflow/server/handlers.py", line 676, in _list_artifacts
    artifact_entities = _get_artifact_repo(run).list_artifacts(path)
AttributeError: 'Response' object has no attribute 'list_artifacts'
```

And even without the `--serve-artifacts` on the `UI Server`, if I start it before the `Artifacts Server`, the experiment is saved with the URI `mlflow-artifacts://0.0.0.0:8001/0`.
Notice that I always create an empty database before starting the servers.

Hi @leviplj I was able to repro your issue with the following configs:

Artifacts server:
```
mlflow server --host 0.0.0.0 \
              --port 5500 \
              --artifacts-destination /tmp/mlflow-testing \
              --backend-store-uri sqlite:///./mlflow-backend-store.db \
              --gunicorn-opts "--log-level debug" \
              --serve-artifacts \
              --artifacts-only
```
Tracking server:
```
mlflow server --host 0.0.0.0 \
              --port 5000 \
              --backend-store-uri sqlite:///./mlflow-backend-store.db \
              --default-artifact-root http://localhost:5500/api/2.0/mlflow-artifacts/artifacts/myruns \
              --gunicorn-opts "--log-level debug"
```
However, by omitting the `backend-store-uri` option from the artifacts server configuration (which is not needed for proxied operation since it is not handling run information, experiment tracking, metrics logging, etc and only handles artifact saving and loading) this should (hopefully) fix your problem. 

Please validate these configs for the servers to ensure that your environment is functioning correctly:

Artifacts server:
```
mlflow server --host 0.0.0.0 \
              --port 5500 \
              --artifacts-destination /tmp/mlflow-testing \
              --gunicorn-opts "--log-level debug" \
              --serve-artifacts \
              --artifacts-only
```
Tracking server:
```
mlflow server --host 0.0.0.0 \
              --port 5000 \
              --backend-store-uri sqlite:///./mlflow-backend-store.db \
              --default-artifact-root http://localhost:5500/api/2.0/mlflow-artifacts/artifacts/myruns \
              --gunicorn-opts "--log-level debug"
```
We're going to be implementing controls for the cli to ensure that these incompatible configurations won't raise these sorts of frustrating problems for server administrators. Stay tuned!

@BenWilson2 that works, but it's using `http` instead of the new schema `mlflow-artifacts:/`. Using `mlflow-artifacts` still breaks the tracking server. If I don't set `--serve-artifacts`, the artifacts fail to return with the message `Unable to list artifacts stored under {artifactUri} for the current run ...` If I set `--serve-artifacts`, no artifact is listed but there's no error message. I guess the main problem is why the servers are behaving differently depending on which server I start first when using `--backend-store-uri` on both servers.
